reviewText:
Eets munchies is a 2D puzzle game for Windows by Klei.

Menu:
I am not afraid to say this is clearly intended for mobile devices. The menu is non existant the only thing i can tell you is that you can turn game music or audio on or off. The game starts windowed and there is no option to fullscreen. You can use Alt+Enter to make it fullscreen regardless and it will nicely scale without changing your resolution. Now in fullscreen the problem is that you can't reach your Windows volume control anymore so you should preset this.

Controls:
You control the game with your mouse. No controller support though that doesn't really fit here anyway. There are moments where you control devices with your keyboard however those are not rebindable.

Ingame:
Ofcourse this is what you really need to look at incase of mobile games. You are presented with colourful worlds in which you need to guide your character Eets through cases of emotional distress and to the cake. Reaching the cake can be easy or very challenging. Remembering that there are physics involved for example shooting Eets off a platform with a cannon. There are a good set of items available to help you progress for example Chili's that make Eets angry and jump higher, Bounce flowers to launch Eets in a set direction or bombs to blow away walls.

Did you beat all the levels? Try some of the user made levels or create your own with the steam workshop or puzzle creator.

Achievements:
There are 14 of them and are mostly linked to beating the game.

DLC:
Not available.

Conclusion:
If you have some spare change and you like cute 2D puzzle games then this is a good one.

Eets Munchies is an adorably animated puzzle game starring a furry white rabbit/flea amalgamation, one which I honestly can't determine if cute or creepy. It's a relatively simple-to-pick up game with basic controls and (for the most part) a friendly interface; this, combined with a gradual learning curve, helps Eets live up to its all-ages claims. It's a surprisingly fun game to play, and I couldn't help but find myself enjoying each level.

-Gameplay & Controls-
The game revolves around placing a series of wooden platforms and powerups while triggering different mechanisms to help our friend Eets get to a brightly colored cake at the end of each level. Along the way, the player can also grab different candies as a sort of optional collectible; gathering the different collectibles became rather challenging as time went on. While the concept is simple, navigating through each puzzle becomes an overall enjoyable experience. With the addition of Steam Workship, the amount of puzzles for Eets to navigate is essentially endless, which should keep at least a few ingenuous players coming back for more.

-Graphics & Visuals-
Despite some initial awkwardness, I found Eets to be rather graphically charming. The different machinations and animals he uses to help him on his way are lively and animated, and I couldn't help but fall in love with the Inhale Whales. Each individual World is visually different, and in some cases rather distinctive, although I have to say that I didn't much like the desert motiff of World Two. However, the game gives off an aura of 2D eye-candy after one's intial impressions, so I have to say I'm rather sold on most of the designs.

-Music & Audio-
The tracks in Eets Munchies are rather upbeat and whimsical, although after making it few the first world or two they start to become repetitive. They're overall quite enjoyable, and they certainly add some appropraite ambience for some an adorable title, but one could have hoped for a bit more diversity as far as music goes.

-Final Thoughts-
Overall, Eets Munchies is a rather enjoyable yet simple experience for the casual puzzle gamer. It's fun and charming, and has a learning curve suitable for just about everyone. I have to say that I wasn't planning on liking the game at all when I first started playing, but it ended up winning me over within the first ten levels, and I found myself striving for every collectible. I think it's worth getting if just to play in some spare time, although I wouldn't say it's meant to be experienced in long sessions as it can struggle as far as holding one's interest. Ultimately, the game is surprisingly fun to play, and I have to say that I would recommend.

reviewText:
Eets Munchies Review

I originally got this game when it was in beta through a Humble Bundle a little while ago. I believe I tried it once and then just never got around to playing it more. When I first tried Eets Munchies I instantly fell in love with the cartoony style and feel of the game. The music is very fitting and also enjoyable to listen to.

That was back in the Beta, now that it has been updated I have to say that I am very impressed. I am so glad I thought of starting this game up again just to see that it now had achievements and steam workshop support to make your own levels! I can definitely see myself playing this for hours just trying to get all the treats in every level.

As for the gameplay, it is a very relaxing and casual indie game with 48 regular levels in 4 differently themed worlds plus a mystery world which has 12 unlockable levels which are significantly more difficult than the other levels in the game. While playing the game you get introduced to a bunch of different mechanics that spice up the puzzle solving quite a bit. The gameplay is very enjoyable and I like the fact that you can switch between three different speeds ranging from slow to fast.

The controls and puzzle maker are great and the animation is bloody fantastic. I recommend this game to anyone who is looking for or want to play a casual and extremely enjoyable game. The concept of having 3 treats to collect in every level and the more treats you collect the more items you unlock in the puzzle maker is great and it makes for a very nice and a little bit addicting game to play when you want to relax from all your hardcore competitive fps shooters(am I right?).

To sign this review off I feel like I need to state that as a person who is a little bit of an achievement junkie or whatnot this game is absolutely worth it, even if it wouldn't have had achievements I would still have recommended it. Although we all love achievements so what is there to complain about? Some people might say that 6,99€ or your regional equivalent is too much to ask for but I don't think so, in my honest opinion this game is worth atleast 7€. My advise is that you should buy this as soon as you get a chance to, but if you don't want to then don't ;)

-Quick Review-
Eets Munchies is a puzzle game that has good humor, fun challenges (however not very challenging… there were a few good ones though) easy achievements, and just a good game to play if you have a few hours to burn. I’d recommend this type of game for a phone, or small portable device.
-Detailed breakdown review-
Story: Your goal is to help Eets (the little white bug looking creature) reach the end of the level, you want to collect the 3 food items also, as an extra challenge. As you collect the food and the cake at the end of the level you unlock items you can use in your own Steamworkshop puzzles.

Game Play: The game itself felt like an app I would play on an apple computer inside the computer store. The buttons themselves actually look like ones used on Angry Birds, so I’m pretty sure that’s how you should be playing this game, but it worked flawlessly with my mouse.
It’s a point and click game, that about sums it up. Before you start the game you are given a select few items to set down, then you play and use those items to help Eets finish the level.

Achievements: I had no trouble with the achievements, once I had finished the game as far as I could go (I only had to skip about 4 levels, and still had most of the secret levels left), the rest of the achievements you can look up helpful guides. Basically think of this game as a free “100%” for your steam profile. Pretty neat, I think. :D

Price: Eets Munchies current price is $6.99, I had actually commented to one of my friends “I’m playing a 5 dollar game… this is great xD  “ I had no idea what the actual price was. I acquired this game through a humblebundle but this is the first time that the price has been nearly spot on for the value. You can play games that will eat up (pun not intended) more time for the same price. But this game is asking a fair price.

Conclusion: I enjoyed the game, it was short, quick, and to the point. I recommend this game.

You might have this game lying around, whether in your Steam Library or Humble Account, and either way I'd say give it a try if you haven't, it's quite a pleasant puzzle game.

The core gameplay of Eets Munchies is very simple - Eets, the white dog-looking guy there, wants the cake, and is very single-minded in this desire. He will walk until he either reaches a wall or obstacle, when he will turn around, or when he reaches a ledge, where he will (usually) jump. This is usually not enough to reach the cake on its own, so you have to help him, using a variety of passive or activated items.

These range from wooden platforms/barricades, or items that will change Eets' mood to angry or frightened. The levels are small and only have a few items each, so it's usually fairly easy to tell what the game wants you to do, but it still feels clever when you pull it off, thanks to the nice animation and relaxing soundtrack. There are some physics and timing related puzzles, but they're not too common and usually not so bad. The game's not very long, so maybe get it on a discount if you don't have it, but if you really like puzzles I'd say it's worth full price.

reviewText:
I have over 600 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game.

One Hour Reviews #55 - Eets Munchies

Eets Munchies is a puzzle game that took me back to my days playing Lemmings.  You play as Eets and his single-minded quest to get cake.  But Eets is not terribly smart.  In fact he'll happily hop of a ledge into oblivion if you let him.

To avoid that, the trick is to strategically place items that will help Eets get to his goal of eating his cake.   You place these items prior to starting the level.  Some items are simple like planks that you can place for Eets to walkover.  But other items that you place you click to interact with, and these items will interact with the environment.  Take for example the Inhale Whale" which you click on and it will inhale Eets and then exhale him to move him up at an angle.

I also was reminded of Angry Birds as I continued to progress through levels and the game would introduce new kinds of items to use that work in different ways.  Another reminder is the way each level has the basic goal of getting to the cake
date: but also a secondary goal of getting up to 3 additional treats.  It's pretty easy to make it to the cake and progress to the next level
recommended: but the game awards you for getting each of the 3 treats as well
hoursPlayed: which is where the game can get tricky.\n\nI adored the art style.  It has a zany cartoon feel
voteText: like something I'd see in Ren & Stimpy.  And the sound effects are matched perfectly with the art.  I thought they did some nice work here.  My only complaint is the music starts feeling repetitive after awhile
helpfulPercent: but as far as complaints go that's pretty minor.\n\nOne other thing that sets this game apart is the level editor.  I thought this was a really cool touch to add.  The level editor is pretty easy to use
votesHelpful: it's basically just drag and drop.  You can build the levels and populate it with the items that you've unlocked from regular play.\n\nI definitely appreciated the inclusion of the level editor as I think that helps add replay value.  I remember playing Angry Birds
votesTotal: and never found myself really replaying levels once I beat them.  I definitely would have felt the same about this game
votesFunny: so it's nice to have the level editor to make your own levels
commentsCount: or get your own from Steam Workshop.\n\nYou might be a little turned off by the price
column16: as there are definitely cheaper puzzle games to be had (particularly on mobile).  But the game is undeniably fun
column17: and given the high potential for replayability
column18: I still think it's a fine value."

What the game did right:

+Implemented different ways to get to your goal
+allowed players to continue to the next puzzle if you didn't get all of the snacks
+introduced new, different mechanics after every few puzzles
+the art style is great for this game and what it is
+the sound effects change in regards to how the character is influenced by the player
+the game play time is there for real puzzle genre players (+1.5 - 3 hours to collect all collectibles)

What the game did wrong:

-the length for casual players (2 hours max)
-the basic solution for the puzzle is often too easy for the casual players (get 1 or 2 snacks just by doing what is obvious)
-mechanics being unreliable at times (getting your character to walk along a path you've built instead of bouncing off of walls or being too scared can get frustrating by slightly altering your paths over and over)

Final thoughts:

I've only put 2 hours into this game playing it casually and I have collected the majority (80+?) snacks and didn't have to put much effort into it. I didn't feel very challenged during this time until i reached the mystery levels where the difficulty spiked to amazing proportions.
The game also feels like a phone app game. Imagine a game that would have micro transactions for puzzle packs but instead you paid 7 dollars to just buy the game at a flat price.

At this time I recommend the game if it is on sale, get it at 5 USD or less. Puzzle genre players should enjoy this one as it does get challenging completing the game 100% and extends the play time; Have fun!
